data.name: REMOTING_HTML
data.value:
Remoting Services
 

Remoting services can be configured to use specific communication channels and the endpoints for remote objects.

Tasks

View Remoting Services Properties

Use the Remoting Services dialog box to view the various remoting services settings.

data.name: CONFIGASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Configured Assemblies
 

Configured assemblies are the assemblies from the assembly cache that have an associated binding policy or codebase.

The two policy settings available determine assembly version binding and assembly codebases. Binding policy allows you to specify a new version of the assembly when an application requests a different version.  Codebases allow you to specify the location of an assembly for a particular version. Codebases are particularly useful if the computer does not already have the version of the assembly needed to run the application.

<*-0-*>

Tasks

View List of Configured Assemblies

Toggle to the list of configured assemblies to see which ones have binding policy and codebases set.

Configure an Assembly

Add another assembly to the Configured Assemblies list. After the assembly has been added, double-click the assembly in the Configured Assemblies list to set its binding policy and codebases.
Show this Help topic by default.
You can use the View menu to toggle between this Help topic and the list view.

data.name: NET_HTML
data.value:
.NET Framework 1.1 Configuration

(version <*-0-*>)
 

.NET Framework 1.1 Configuration allows you to configure assemblies, remoting services, and code access security policy specific to version 1.1 of the .NET Framework.

Note: This version of the .NET Framework Configuration tool will not adjust settings for previous or later versions of the .NET Framework. Use the corresponding configuration tool to adjust settings for those versions.

Tasks

Manage the Assembly Cache

The assembly cache stores assemblies that are designed to be shared by several applications. Use the assembly cache to view, add, and remove the managed components that are installed on this computer.

Managed Configured Assemblies

Configured assemblies are the set of assemblies from the assembly cache that have an associated set of rules. These rules can determine which version of the assembly gets loaded and the location used to load the assembly.

Configure Code Access Security Policy

The common language runtime uses code access security to control applications' access to protected resources. Each application's assemblies are evaluated and assigned permissions based on factors that include the assembly's origin and author.

Adjust Remoting Services

Use the Remoting Services Properties dialog box to adjust communication channels for all applications on this computer.

Manage Individual Applications

Each application can have its own set of configured assemblies and remoting services.

<*-1-*>

data.name: GENSEC_HTML
data.value:
Code Access Security Policy
 

The common language runtime's code access security system determines an assembly's permissions to access protected resources.  Each permission set granted to an assembly is based on the assembly's evidence (such as its URL or publisher certificate), which in turn is based on configurable security policy.

To learn more about the code access security model, refer to the Microsoft .NET Framework SDK documentation.

The wizards and task links below will help you set and distribute security policy.  For complete control of security policy, use the tree views under this node.

Tasks

Increase Assembly Trust

Use the Trust an Assembly wizard to increase the level of trust granted to a particular assembly. This wizard modifies security policy based on information about the evidence of the assembly selected.

Adjust Zone Security

Use the Security Adjustment Wizard to modify the level of trust granted to all assemblies coming from a particular zone, such as Internet, Local Intranet, or My Computer.

Evaluate Assembly

Use the Evaluate an Assembly wizard to evaluate what permissions or code groups apply to a particular assembly. This is useful in determining the effect of current security policy on actual assemblies.

Create Deployment Package

Use the Deployment Package Wizard to create a policy deployment package. The wizard wraps a security policy level into a Windows Installer Package (.msi file) that can then be distributed using Group Policy or Microsoft Systems Management Server.

Reset All Policy Levels

Use this task to reset your security policy to the default settings. Note that this will obliterate all modifications that might have been made to default security policy.

data.name: GENAPP_HTML
data.value:
Applications
 

View and configure managed applications previously configured by this tool.

Note: The .NET Framework Configuration tool does not list all managed applications installed on this computer, nor does it list all managed applications that have configuration files.

Tasks

Add an Application to Configure

Use this task to add a new application to the list of applications in this tool. Once the application has been added, you can edit its individual configured assemblies and remoting services.

Fix an Application

Use the Application Restore tool to examine an application and detect problems associated with its dependencies. The tool can modify the applications configuration file to fix detected dependency problems so that the application runs as expected.

data.name: SINGLEAPPLICATION_HTML
data.value:
<*-0-*>
 

Location: <*-1-*>

This application can have its own configured assemblies and remoting services.  These settings only affect this one application.  Use the tasks below to get started.

Tasks

View the Application's Properties

Use the application's Properties dialog box to make changes to garbage collection, publisher policy, and the private path used to find additional assemblies.

<*-2-*>

View the Assembly Dependencies

Assembly dependencies are the assemblies that make up the application.  These assemblies can be used to create configured assemblies.

<*-3-*>

Managed Configured Assemblies

Configured assemblies are the set of assemblies from the assembly cache that have an associated set of rules.  These rules can determine which version of the assembly gets loaded and the location used to load the assembly.

Adjust Remoting Services

Use the Remoting Services dialog box to adjust communication channels and object endpoints.

Fix this Application

Use the Application Restore tool to examine this application and detect problems associated with its dependencies. The tool can modify this applications configuration file to fix detected dependency problems so that the application runs as expected.

data.name: SHAREDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Cache
 

The assembly cache contains the set of assemblies available to all applications targeting the .NET Framework.  Multiple versions of the same assembly can be placed in the assembly cache.  This allows two applications to correctly execute even if they require different versions of the same shared assembly.

Tasks

View List of Assemblies in the Assembly Cache

Toggle to the list of assemblies in the assembly cache.

Add an Assembly to the Assembly Cache

This copies an assembly file into the cache.  After the assembly has been added, the assembly can be used as a configured assembly or added to the Policy Assemblies list.
Show this Help topic by default.
You can use the View menu to toggle between this Help topic and the list view.

data.name: SINGLECODEGROUP_HTML
data.value:
<*-0-*> Code Group
 

Description:
<*-1-*>

Assembly evidence must match this membership condition to belong to the code group: <*-2-*>.

Assemblies matching the membership condition are granted this permission set at the current policy level: <*-3-*>.

Permission Set Description:
<*-4-*>

<*-5-*>

<*-6-*>
Tasks

Edit Code Group Properties

The Code Group Properties dialog box allows you to edit this code group's name, description, membership condition, and permission set.

Add a Child Code Group

Use the Create Code Group wizard to add a new code group as a child to this code group. You will be able to choose its name, description, membership condition, and permission set.
<*-7-*>

data.name: CODEGROUPS_HTML
data.value:
Code Groups
 

Security policy is configured using a hierarchy of code groups at every policy level. Default security policy consists of union code groups, which combine the permissions of all matching child code groups with their own permissions, and some custom code groups. Every union code group has a membership condition and a permission set. If an assembly's evidence matches the membership condition on such a code group, the associated permission set is granted to the assembly at that policy level. If more than one union code group matches, the combination of their permission sets is granted.

A union code group can have zero or more child code groups. A child code group contributes to the permission set granted for an assembly only when both its own and its parent code group's membership conditions are met. If a code group's membership condition fails to match the evidence, any child code groups will be ignored.

Custom code groups have specialized behavior defined by the code group developer and might or might not follow the behavior outlined above. Custom code groups cannot be directly edited using this tool.

data.name: FULLTRUSTASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Policy Assemblies
 

Policy assemblies are assemblies used during policy evaluation of a policy level by the security system.  If you add a custom security object such as a custom permission or custom membership condition to policy, be sure to add the assembly implementing the custom object and all the assemblies it depends on to this list.  The policy system will grant these assemblies full trust for the policy level to which this list belongs.

Tasks

View Policy Assemblies

Toggle to the list of assemblies that are used during this level's policy evaluation.
Show this Help topic by default.
You can use the View menu to toggle between this Help topic and the list view.

data.name: WAITINGDEPENDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Dependencies
 

Assembly dependencies are the set of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.

Note: This application is still waiting to have its list of assembly dependencies generated.

Tasks

Generate List of Assembly Dependencies

This interrupts the .NET Framework Configuration tool and causes it to generate the list of assembly dependencies for this application immediately.

data.name: DEPENDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Dependencies
 

Assembly dependencies are the set of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.

Note: Applications can use assemblies in a way that prevents them from showing up in this list. Therefore, this list is not the guaranteed list of all dependencies for this application.

Tasks

View Assembly Dependencies

Toggle to the list of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.
Show this Help topic by default.
You can use the View menu to toggle between this Help topic and the list view.

data.name: LOADINGDEPENDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Dependencies
 

Assembly dependencies are the set of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.

The .NET Framework Configuration tool is currently generating the list of assembly dependencies for this application.  Please be patient; this might take some time depending on the location of this application's dependencies.

data.name: ERRORDEPENDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Dependencies
 

Assembly dependencies are the set of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.

Unfortunately, the .NET Framework Configuration tool cannot show this list of assembly dependencies for this application due to an error during the generation of the list.

data.name: UNMANAGEDDEPENDASSEM_HTML
data.value:
Assembly Dependencies
 

Assembly dependencies are the set of assemblies this application needs to be able to run.

The application you've selected does not execute using the .NET Framework.  Therefore, the .NET Framework Configuration tool cannot determine the assemblies it might use.

Note: This application can still use assemblies; however, the application itself is not an assembly and therefore does not list the assemblies it uses. You can still add binding policy and codebases for assemblies using this application's Configured Assemblies node.

data.name: NONUNIONCODEGROUP_HTML
data.value:
Non-union code group

<*-0-*> Code Group
 

<*-1-*>

The code group you selected is a custom code group that cannot be directly edited using this tool.

Tasks

View Custom Code Group Properties

Use the Properties dialog box to view the XML describing the selected code group. Please follow the documentation of the custom code group provider if you wish to change settings on this code group.

data.name: FULLTRUST_HTML
data.value:
<*-0-*>
 

This permission set gives code unrestricted access to all protected resources. Managed code receives this permission if it is a member of a code group associated with this permission set.

This can be a very dangerous permission set; it allows full access to your computer's resources such as the file system or network access, potentially operating outside the control of the security system. If you are modifying security policy, be sure to set policy such that only assemblies you fully trust could possibly get this permission set.

data.name: SECURITYPOLICY_HTML
data.value:
<*-0-*> Policy
 

There are three configurable policy levels (enterprise, machine, and user) that the security system uses to determine what permissions an assembly receives. Each policy level contains code groups, permission sets, and a list of policy assemblies, all of which are configurable using this tool.

The enterprise level is the highest, describing security policy for an entire enterprise. Below that, machine policy applies to all code run on that computer. User policy is a third level that can be defined based on the currently logged-on user. When security policy is evaluated, enterprise, machine, and user levels are separately evaluated and intersected - meaning that code is granted the minimum set of permissions granted by any of the levels.

Expand this node to edit code groups, permission sets, or the list of policy assemblies.

<*-1-*>

This policy level file is located at: <*-2-*>

<*-3-*>

data.name: PERMISSIONSETS_HTML
data.value:
Permission Sets
 

Permission sets are comprised of zero or more permissions. Each permission expresses a specific level of authorization to access a protected resource such as the file system, the network, and many others.

<*-0-*>
Tasks

Create New Permission Set

The Create Permission Set wizard allows you to create a new permission set. A new permission set can be built from the permissions defined by the .NET Framework or by importing custom permissions.
<*-1-*>

data.name: SINGLEPERMISSIONSET_HTML
data.value:
<*-0-*> Permission Set
 

<*-1-*>

Tasks

View Permissions

This allows you to view the permissions in this permission set and to view and modify individual permissions by right-clicking them in the permission list.

<*-2-*>

Change Permissions

The Configure an Assembly wizard allows you to add or remove permissions from this permission set. This wizard also allows you to modify permissions in this permission set by selecting a permission and clicking Properties.

Rename Permission Set

This option allows you to give this permission set another name. Be careful when renaming permission sets, as code groups depending on the old name might also need to be updated.

<*-3-*>
Show this Help topic by default.
You can use the View menu to toggle between this Help topic and the list view.
